thread.title: Will climate change cause a population surge?
thread.title_full: Will climate change cause a population surge? | www.kirotv.com

author: kirotv.com
title: Will climate change cause a population surge?
text:
Will climate change cause a surge in population growth in the Pacific Northwest?
There's been a lot of speculation about the subject, and University of Washington researchers say they don’t know but it’s a possibility.
“It's still an open question,” said Lara Whitely Binder, outreach specialist at UW’s Climate Impacts Group. “The question is will it be detectable?”
UW grad student Alison Saperstein penned a first-of-its-kind report called “Climate Change, Migration, and the Puget Sound Region." Whitely Binder is Saperstein’s advisor.
Whitely Binder said climate change is happening right now, but it's too soon to tell whether that alone will cause mass migration. She said it's usually a combination of factors.
“Economic opportunity is a very critical component to that decision, also the availability of social networks like friends or family,” Whitely Binder explained.
Seattleites hope city planning can keep up with the influx of people.
“The systems have to work,” Nicole Swedberg said. “As things get bigger and bigger, we have to change our system(s) so they work. Water, education, whatever those systems are.”
“On a personal level, I'm more thoughtful about how I go about my day,” added Cheri Herzer, “I kind of schedule my day around the traffic,”
Whitely Binder said there are implications on our infrastructure and she hopes their findings can help influence public policy.
“We know that climate change is occurring, and now the question is can we slow that train down and eventually stop it?” Whitely Binder said.
Experts say even if climate change starts to affect our population growth, we wouldn't see a spike for at least a few decades
